user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_ResetState:
```c
void UT_ResetState(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr;
    int32                i;

    StubPtr = UT_StubTable;
    for (i = 0; i < UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS; ++i)
    {
        if (FuncKey == 0 || StubPtr->FuncKey == FuncKey)
        {
            UT_ClearStubEntry(StubPtr);
        }
        ++StubPtr;
    }
    if (FuncKey == 0)
    {
        UT_MaxStubSearchLen = 0;
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function UT_ResetState:
typedef struct
{
    UT_EntryType_t EntryType;
    uint32         ModeFlags;
    UT_EntryKey_t  FuncKey;
    UT_EntryData_t Data;
} UT_StubTableEntry_t
...
typedef cpuaddr UT_EntryKey_t
...
static UT_StubTableEntry_t UT_StubTable[UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS] = {{0}}
...
#define UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS 200
...
static uint32              UT_MaxStubSearchLen             = 0
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
UT_ClearStubEntry(StubPtr);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the shown code. UT_ResetState passes StubPtr that iterates over valid elements of UT_StubTable (size UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS), so the call UT_ClearStubEntry(StubPtr) itself does not cause an out‑of‑bounds access. A violation would only occur if UT_ClearStubEntry internally used a <string.h> function (e.g. strcpy, memcpy, memset, etc.) with an incorrect size/length that exceeded the bounds of the object pointed to by StubPtr (for example, calling memcpy(StubPtr, src, n) where n > sizeof *StubPtr, or strcpy into a fixed buffer inside the entry when the source is too large). Based on the provided code, no such internal misuse is shown.
